text:
When I try to stop the Apache server, it seems to be trying to stop for a 
couple of minutes, then my computer reboots without any warning. I have tried 
to stop the server three times and got a reboot each time.
creator: eric.pauker@telus.net

text:
The Zone Alarm bug has nothing to do with this bug, I am not using Zone Alarm 
and I didn't say anything about getting a BSOD. The Apache server refuses to 
shut down and while attempting to shut down it reboots my computer.

Here's what happens:

1. I select "stop" from the Apache menu off the start button, or I select stop 
in the Apache server monitor, or I select the Apache server in the services 
list and then select stop.

2. The server spends a couple of minutes trying to stop.

3. My monitor goes black (no warnings or messages of any kind), and my computer 
reboots.

And are you running any other firewall, anti-virus program, or other
program that places with winsock/the tcp/ip stack?
creator: slive@apache.org
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Please detail exactly what antivirus or firewall software is installed
  on this specific PC.  Please indiciate exactly which version of the OS.
  And finally, please inidicate exactly what Network drivers are installed
  (protocol, interfaces and adaptors) for the given network.

My system specs:

- No firewall running.
- No Antivirus running.
- Standard Windows 2000 TCP/IP network drivers.
- Realtek RTL8139(A) PCI Fast Ethernet Apdapter card installed, using Microsoft 
driver 5.366.818.1999.
- Microsoft Windows 2000 Professional Version 5.0.2195 Service Pack 1 Build 
2195 NOTE: I have tried to install service pack 2 and 3 in the past and each 
time they have trashed my system, so it is not an option for me to try them.


I pressed ctrl-alt-del to see what processes were running on my machine, and I 
noticed that Apache.exe was in the list three times. Is this normal?
creator: eric.pauker@telus.net
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Apache.exe should be running twice (a parent 'watchdog' process that assures
  the server remainins running in case of some fault, and a child 'worker'
  process that serves requests.)  You will note that the child consumes many
  more resources than the parent.

  ApacheMonitor.exe may be running if you have the monitor running in the
  taskbar, displaying the status of the running apache process.

  You mention both SP2 and SP3 'trash' your system.  If the system is that
  unstable, there is possibly no help we can provide.

  Finally, you mention you can't 'stop' apache, and it reboots your machine 
  when you attempt to stop it.  How are you stopping apache?  Is it running
  as a service, or as a console application?

I mentioned in a previous post how I attempt to stop Apache. Basically I have 
tried every possible way to stop it and none have worked. It is running as a 
service.

I don't have the Apache monitor running, it is Apache.exe that appears three 
times in the process list.

As far as the service packs go, they are buggy pieces of junk. I have tried 
reformatting my harddrive, installing just Windows 2000 and then the service 
packs. They trash Windows 2000 every time. I worked for a government office a 
couple of years ago, and the network techs there discovered that the Windows 
2000 service packs would trash any machine that had a certain Intel motherboard 
in it, so they made a policy that no service packs would be installed ever. 
They verified with Microsoft that there is a problem with the service packs on 
certain motherboards, but MS decided it wasn't worth their time to fix it.
creator: eric.pauker@telus.net

text:
I've had the reboot problem on win2k with other network software (a java proxy
for example), but not (yet?) with apache. I'd say this looks like a serious
problem in windows' tcp/ip module (in conclusion with some hardware as you
mentioned).

You may try another network card or something (was helpful in my case). There's
probably nothing that we can do within the apache code. Therefore I'm marking
this report invalid. Sorry.

Thanks for using Apache!
creator: nd@perlig.de
